habitat: Forested landscapes with nearby wetlands, bogs, ponds, and streams; uses dense conifer cover in winter and aquatic areas in summer for cooling.
diet: Browser; twigs, buds, leaves of trees and shrubs, and aquatic vegetation in warm months.
activityPattern: Most active at dawn and dusk (crepuscular), but can be active day or night.
conservationStatus: IUCN: Least Concern (global); local populations can fluctuate due to parasites, heat stress, and habitat factors.
description: Largest member of the deer family, adapted to cold climates; powerful swimmer and can be defensive, especially cows with calves and bulls during rut.

sources.title: NH PBS NatureWorks: Moose
USFS WMNF About the Area (wildlife mentions moose)

habitat: Forests and wooded mountain landscapes with cover and seasonal food sources (mast, berries); uses dens in winter in colder areas.
diet: Omnivore; largely plant-based with nuts, berries, buds, plus insects, carrion, and occasional small mammals/fish.
activityPattern: Often crepuscular; can be active day or night depending on food and disturbance.
description: Medium-sized bear of WMNF; generally solitary; strong sense of smell; conflicts usually involve food access.

sources.title: NH PBS NatureWorks: American Black Bear
USFS WMNF About the Area (wildlife)

habitat: Mixed forests, edges, and regenerating stands; in northern NH often uses dense spruce–fir stands as winter cover (“deer yards”).
diet: Browser and grazer; leaves, twigs, buds, mast, and herbaceous plants.
activityPattern: Crepuscular; often active at dawn and dusk.
description: Adaptable deer common in WMNF valleys and edges; winter survival in northern areas depends on cover and snow conditions.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (winter cover for deer)
USFS WMNF About the Area (mentions white tail deer)

habitat: Varied—forests, edges, wetlands, and developed landscapes; uses WMNF mosaic for travel and hunting.
diet: Opportunistic omnivore/carnivore; small mammals, carrion, fruit, and occasionally deer (especially fawns or carcasses).
description: Highly adaptable canid present throughout northern New England; travels long distances and uses mixed habitats.

sources.title: USFS WMNF About the Area (wildlife diversity context)
UNH Extension: Woodlands and Wildlife (mentions wildlife in forest types)

habitat: Forests, rocky ledges, and mixed landscapes; uses cover for stalking prey.
activityPattern: Mostly crepuscular/nocturnal; can be active daytime.
conservationStatus: Generally stable regionally; status varies locally.
description: Medium-sized wild cat with tufted ears and short tail; secretive and rarely seen despite being present.

sources.title: Animal Diversity Web: Lynx rufus (bobcat)
USFS WMNF About the Area (wildlife diversity)

habitat: Rivers, streams, ponds, and wetlands; creates impoundments that shape WMNF wetland mosaics.
diet: Herbivore; bark, twigs, aquatic plants, and woody vegetation (especially in winter).
description: Large semi-aquatic rodent that builds dams and lodges; beaver wetlands increase habitat diversity for many species.

sources.title: NH PBS NatureWorks: Beaver
UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (notes beaver impoundments)

habitat: Forests (conifer and mixed) where it can feed on bark and foliage; common in northern forests.
diet: Herbivore; leaves, buds, twigs, bark; conifers important in winter.
activityPattern: Mostly nocturnal, but can be active in daylight.
description: Slow-moving rodent armed with quills; climbs trees to feed; an important prey item for fishers.

sources.title: NH PBS NatureWorks: Fisher (porcupine predation described)
UNH Extension: Woodlands and Wildlife (mentions porcupines in mature forests)

habitat: Conifer and mixed forests; common in spruce–fir where it feeds on cones and fungi.
diet: Seeds from conifer cones, fungi, buds, fruit; opportunistic.
description: Small territorial squirrel known for loud chatter; caches cones and fungi, influencing seed dispersal and forest regeneration.

sources.title: UNH Extension: High-Elevation Forests (spruce–fir wildlife use)
UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (wildlife context)

habitat: Dense conifer and young mixed forests, especially spruce–fir; uses thick cover for predator avoidance.
diet: Herbivore; twigs, buds, bark in winter; leaves and herbs in summer.
conservationStatus: Common boreal-associated species in northern forests.
description: A northern hare adapted to deep snow with large feet; key prey for many predators in spruce–fir food webs.

sources.title: NH PBS Wildlife Journal Junior: Snowshoe hare
UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (mentions snowshoe hares)

habitat: Rivers, streams, ponds, wetlands; needs open water access in winter where available.
diet: Carnivore; primarily fish and aquatic prey (also amphibians/crustaceans).
conservationStatus: Generally common; status varies by state.
description: Playful semi-aquatic mustelid; indicator of healthy aquatic systems; travels along waterways.

sources.title: USFS FEIS species review: Lontra canadensis
USFS WMNF About the Area (wetlands/streams context)

habitat: Thick coniferous or mixed conifer–hardwood forests with den sites (hollow trees, logs).
diet: Carnivore/omnivore; small mammals, snowshoe hares, and notably porcupines; also fruit/carrion.
description: A large mustelid and one of the few effective predators of porcupines; uses forest cover and complex structure.

sources.title: NH PBS NatureWorks: Fisher
UNH Extension: Woodlands and Wildlife (mentions fishers in mature forest)

habitat: Primarily conifer and mixed forests with complex structure and deep snow cover in winter; associated with boreal/spruce–fir habitats in northern New England.
diet: Carnivore/omnivore; small mammals, birds, insects, berries (seasonal).
activityPattern: Mostly crepuscular/nocturnal; active year-round, often hunting under snow in winter.
conservationStatus: Threatened in New Hampshire (state-level) per UNH Extension summary; status varies regionally.
description: A small, agile mustelid of northern forests; sensitive to habitat fragmentation and reliant on forest complexity and prey availability.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (mentions American marten threatened in NH)
UNH Extension: Woodlands and Wildlife (spruce–fir wildlife list includes pine marten)

habitat: Mixed forests and early successional/aspen-birch stands; uses dense young growth for cover.
diet: Buds, leaves, fruit, and insects (especially for chicks).
conservationStatus: Common game bird; populations fluctuate with habitat and cycles.
description: Forest grouse known for the male’s drumming display; benefits from a mosaic of young forest and mature cover.

sources.title: USFS WMNF About the Area (mentions ruffed grouse)
All About Birds: Ruffed Grouse life history

habitat: High-elevation or otherwise cold-climate spruce–fir forests with dense, often stunted/regenerating structure (including balsam fir); favors edges/gaps for nesting.
diet: Insects and other arthropods; also small fruit when available.
activityPattern: Diurnal (most detectable by song at dawn).
conservationStatus: High conservation concern; WMNF notes major breeding habitat block; Cornell notes significant declines and high concern ranking.
description: A secretive montane thrush strongly associated with spruce–fir habitats; one of the WMNF’s signature conservation-priority birds.

sources.title: USFS WMNF About the Area (Bicknell’s Thrush breeding habitat)
Cornell All About Birds: Bicknell’s Thrush life history
UNH Extension: High-Elevation Forests (spruce–fir elevation band)

habitat: Cliffs and open landscapes for hunting; nests on ledges and hunts over valleys, rivers, and open areas including WMNF notches.
conservationStatus: Recovered from historical declines in many areas; local protections may apply at nesting cliffs.
description: Fast-flying raptor associated with cliff nesting; WMNF and surrounding White Mountains host notable cliff habitats.

sources.title: All About Birds: Peregrine Falcon life history
USFS WMNF About the Area (wildlife diversity context)
